Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of TGF-β Signaling Inhibition in AVF Patency in CKD

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial involved C57BL/6J mice subjected to 5/6 nephrectomy to induce CKD, with 0/6 and 3/6 nephrectomy as controls.

Intervention.evidence: AVF were created in mice with TGF-βR1/R2 knockdown in endothelial or smooth muscle cells.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether inhibiting endothelial TGF-β signaling can prevent AVF failure by reducing endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was AVF patency, assessed over 42 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 120 mice were randomised: 60 to the intervention and 60 to the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Inhibition of TGF-β signaling decreased smooth muscle cell proliferation, reduced wall thickness, and improved AVF patency.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by NIH grants R01-HL128406, R01-HL144476, R01-HL162580, R01-HL152197, R01-HL146723, R01-HL155105, China Scholarship Council, and VA Connecticut Healthcare System.
